reviewerName: Brian H. "Host of Stage & Screen radio show"
reviewText: When "Shout at the Devil" came out on Beta hi-fi thanks to the folks at Magnetic Video Corporation (remember that awesome-for-its-time rudimentary mirror image MVC logo and cheesy music?), it was intact and looked fine. But like so many other MVC releases, somehow the nice print they used vanished when the film ultimately hit DVD. Such was the fate of "Shout at the Devil," which was released in England with a handsome, professionally designed jacket but with a lousy transfer that looked like someone pulled a 16mm TV release version of the film from the bottom of the kitchen garbage pail, wiped off the coffee grounds (which are compostable, incidentally, and ought not be in your kitchen garbage can to begin with) and duplicated it to DVD. Entire scenes, such as the pivotal "tax collector" sequence, were completely gone except for a tantalizing first minute or so. Color and quality changed with each reel change.But rejoice! This magnificent adventure opus is restored, looks fantastic and looks even more gorgeous on Blu-ray. Peter Hunt's deft direction and attention to detail moves the film along at a handsome clip while maintaining the integrity of Wilbur Smith's novel. The beautiful location footage is as much travelogue as it is integral to the tale, and clearly, Sir Roger Moore and the late Lee Marvin evidently had a lot of fun making it. The audio is crisp and fresh, and Maurice Jarre's sweeping score never sounded better (except on the recently reissued soundtrack CD, of course).Lovers of great adventure films with actual plots and character development, rather than just explosions and car chases, will be as delighted as I am to at last have this treasure in our video libraries.

reviewText: I saw this movie as a kid and always liked it. It was different from the Lee Marvin and Roger Moore movies they usually made. I read the book by Wilbur Smith last year and loved it. The movie follows it closely, and you will not be disappointed. Buy the bluray DVD version because it follows the original release. Roger Moore and Lee Marvin have never been better!David Lucero, author.
summary: A Classic Movie That Follows The Book

reviewText: Lest we forget, while he was an admirable 007 during the 70's and 80's Roger Moore was also the stalwart British hero in a number of terrific adventure movies during the same period including "Gold", The Sea Wolves", "ffolkes" and "The Wild Geese" and this film  "Shout at the Devil" holds it's own very well.  Directed by the Peter Hunt, one of the greatest aciton film directors to ever live, (yes you can quote me on that) who also helmed the terrific "On  Her Majesty's Secret Service", the aforementioned "Gold" and "Death Hunt", "Shout at the Devil" hits the bullseye across the board.  Many of these films I mentioned, including this one, used the same behind the scenes crew that were used on the eraly James Bond classics and it shows.  Although Lee Marvin is, well, a bit over the top at times, I can't recommend this movie enough.  I've waited years for it's release, and now here it is in Blu-ray no less.  Buy it; you won't regret it.
summary: They just don't make them like this anymore

reviewText: UPDATE: October 23, 2013. BLU-RAY + DVD - SHOUT AT THE DEVIL - Lee Marvin, Roger Moore....Well!! I finally got my copy from Amazon, last week, of the new Blu-Ray + DVD version of Shout At The Devil.The picture is clear and the sound is good on both versions.Amazon shows it as 1.85 widescreen format, which should be corrected.The Blu-Ray/DVD package description reads 2.35:1 Widescreen format, Dolby Digital Mono and Runtime approximate at 150 minutes. The full version.SPECIAL FEATURES: they only got a Photo Gallery of scenes from the movie.There are no Scene Selections or Subtitles to choose from, which would have been nice. But I can do without.On the whole, it is great to see this movie as it should be seen. This is the full version. I totally enjoy it. I recommend this movie to all who have waited for this new Blu-Ray/DVD version to come out. ENJOY!!!========================================================================================================================================================================================================I never saw it in a theater, but have seen it on TV. Enjoyed this movie with Roger Moore and Lee Marvin. Great adventure story taking place in Africa just before and after the outbreak of World War One. Partially based on a true incident involving a German warship taking refuge in the Rufiji River to make repairs. Roger Moore and Lee Marvin are teamed up to help the British in trying to destroy the warship. There are other events in the movie that lead them to this final climax that makes for great adventure story.There have been so many boot-legged versions over the years with poor quality and edited 2 hour versions, it's about time this movie got its full release.I'm glad to see this movie finally coming out October 8, 2013 on Blue Ray and DVD. This will be the full version running at 150 minutes.Looking forward to the October release of SHOUT AT THE DEVIL.
summary: UPDATE - Shout at the Devil - Blue Ray/DVD October 23, 2013

reviewText: An American International release ( I want to say 1975 ) with Lee Marvin and Roger Moore in southern Africa at the onset of WWI.  A good natured, humor romp through most of the film, though it does get darker after Barbara Parkins baby is killed.  Not the greatest transfer and my copy has little skips.  Still a watchable product from China, just remember to turn off the subtitles first!  Lee Marvin was the archytpal tough guy in most of his career but could be incredibly effective in lighter roles with comedy -- a forte of Roger Moore.  By and large a fun film.  Directed by Peter Hunt ( ON HER MAJESTY'S SECRET SERVICE -- one of the best Bond films ever).  A good time is guarenteed for all -- as the Beatles said in Mr Kite.

reviewText: This is far from a classic, but fans of Lee Marvin will be well rewarded with a flamboyant performance, and fans of Roger Moore with.. well, a standard Roger Moore performance.Story is based on Wilbur Smiths novel of the same name, and loosely based around real events, albeit with fictional characters.  Roger Moores Englishman forms an unlikely alliance with Lee Marvin's alcoholic rogue, firstly in the poaching game, and latterly in the fight against the Germans, 1914 style, in Zanzibar.  One of the oddest casting decisions is Ian Holm as a loyal mute native!The story has some appeal for looking at a time and location seldom visited by the cinema, but is hampered by vacillating wildy in tone - what starts as a light hearted buddy movie becomes something more grim as the war against Fleisher the German sadististic local officer becomes revenge, and ultimately climaxes in the battle on the German battleship.The directing by Peter Hunt, who directed On Her Majestys Secret Service, has its own style, but has dated - and even then does not settle on side of farce or thriller.  It is best however when skulking around and mounting tension in the final scenes.  It is somewhat of an irony to see how Hunt would have directed Moore in a Bond movie!  Hunt also pulled along another Bond veteran, John Glenn, who directed the action scenes for Hunt as second unit director and fulfills that role again here.  He rightly went on as a successful director of Bond movies in his own right.  Also present from Bond movie lore is Maurice Binder, who famously designed the titles for Bond movies - he performs the same function here albeit in more workmanlike fashion.If you are thinking of buying - beware - the movie is washed out in colour, and sound is of low quality.  Bizarrely, the German speaking scenes which were originally in English, have been dubbed into German - but not subtitled in English!  Since many key scenes are in German, this is a near fatal flaw.Basically it is a gung ho action movie with buddy movie elements, but is uneven in tone and lacking in clarity of vision, although illuminating an intriguing era in WW I history.

reviewText: A beautiful transfer of the film that is the complete 150 minute version.  I still wonder if some of the battle scenes were toned down to obtain a PG rating.  Several shots of violence during the hillside attack appear to have been trimmed to hide a soldier run over by a heavy cart and another warrior who has his head cut off.  A final act of revenge near the conclusion also appears to have been edited to remove more graphic bullet wounds.  Still, a magnificent movie.
summary: Very nice edition of the complete version.
Title: N/A
